raw_text:
Ban on hunting comes into force
 
 Fox hunting with dogs is now illegal in England and Wales after a ban on the activity came into force overnight.
 
 The law faces a stiff test this weekend, with the Countryside Alliance saying many hunts will be out in force. Chief police officers spokesman Nigel Yeo said he expected most people would obey the law - by drag hunting or chasing foxes then shooting them. He said police would challenge the "one of two isolated hunts" which are threatening to break the law.
 
 But Simon Hart of the Countryside Alliance has questioned how police will ensure there are no violations. "The definitions of legal and illegal hunting are so blurred that the police are being asked to make impossible judgements. "You can hunt a rat, but not a mouse, a rabbit but not a hare, an artificial scent, but not a real one," he said.
 
 The Attorney General, Lord Goldsmith, has so far issued no instructions to police on how they should deal with hunters who violate the law. He said he will consult the Director of Public Prosecutions and the police "in the near future" to decide what measures to take with regards to hunting prosecutions. He has rejected a "blanket policy" of not enforcing the ban until the House of Lords has considered its legality. John Cooper, a barrister and chairman of the League Against Cruel Sports, said the anti-hunting lobby expects the authorities to prosecute wherever there is clear evidence of illegal hunting practices. He said police had "acknowledged their duty to investigate allegations of hunting offences".
 
 The Beaufort Hunt had one pack out on Thursday and has promised a hunt this weekend. Under the new law hunters have a number of legal options available to them.
 
 As well as being able to mount a hunt for an artificial scent, it will still be legal for the hunts to "flush out" foxes, as long as they shoot their quarry rather than set the hounds on them. "We are not going away. We will keep these hounds going, we will keep this community going and in the end we will come back and hunt when hunting is legal again," hunt master, Captain Ian Farquhar, said. But Tony Banks, Labour MP for West Ham, said the issue would soon disappear, and that "people in a few years time will be wondering what it was all about". He said had the government not prevaricated since 1997 in introducing the ban, hunting with dogs would have passed into history like other former country pursuits such as otter hunting and badger baiting. "Let the election decide this because the Conservatives have made clear that if they get elected into government they will restore hunting," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Ban on hunting with dogs comes into force in England and Wales, banning fox hunting. Police are expected to challenge hunts with dogs, but the Countryside Alliance argues this is impossible due to blurred definitions of legal and illegal hunting. The Attorney General has not issued instructions on how police should handle hunting cases, instead saying they will consult with prosecutors later.
llama3.2:3b: New law banning fox hunting comes into force in England and Wales, with police expected to challenge most hunts but unclear how they will enforce it. Countryside Alliance leader Simon Hart questions police ability to make impossible judgments, while Attorney General Lord Goldsmith plans to consult with the Director of Public Prosecutions and police on measures for prosecutions.
gemma2:2b: A ban on fox hunting with dogs came into effect in England and Wales, but the Countryside Alliance is challenging the legality of the ban while police prepare to enforce it.  The Attorney General has not yet issued specific guidance for law enforcement on how to address potential violations. The League Against Cruel Sports expects the authorities to prosecute illegal hunting practices, while some argue that hunting will eventually be legalized again.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The new law banning fox hunting in England and Wales has come into force, with penalties for those found violating the ban including fines up to £250, 000 and imprisonment. The law aims to protect public interest by stopping people from taking down foxes without permission. However, some hunters are concerned about how police will enforce the new laws and what measures they can take against violators.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK bans fox hunting with dogs in England and Wales, effective immediately. Despite police challenging some hunts, many continue, likely using alternative methods. The ban faces enforcement challenges due to blurred legal definitions of what is considered "hunting." Lord Goldsmith has not issued instructions on how law enforcement should handle violators, while the anti-hunting lobby expects prosecutions. Hunt master Captain Ian Farquhar plans to maintain his pack despite the ban. Some expect the issue will become less pressing in the future, potentially leading to its historical extinction along with other past pursuits like otter hunting and badger baiting.
qwen2.5:3b: Fox hunting with dogs is now illegal in England and Wales after a ban came into effect overnight. Police expect most people to follow the law, either through drag hunting or shooting foxes. However, some organizations like the Countryside Alliance are concerned about enforcement, questioning unclear definitions of legal versus illegal hunting practices. Chief police officers believe they will challenge isolated hunts breaking the law. The Attorney General has not yet issued instructions on how to handle such cases and expects consultations with prosecutors and police before making a decision. Despite challenges, hunt masters have stated their intention to continue activities under new rules. Labour MP Tony Banks predicts this issue will fade as hunting with dogs is seen as extinct like other outdated pursuits.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. Let me read through each paragraph carefully.

The first sentence is about the ban on fox hunting in England and Wales becoming illegal overnight. So, summarizing that part would be straightforward: Fox hunting with dogs is now illegal in England and Wales.

Next, the article mentions that many hunts are still happening legally, especially because of possible measures like drag hunting or chase hunting followed by shooting. The Chief Police Spokesman, Nigel Yeo, is expected to handle most cases by allowing people to hunt through these methods but is also expected to challenge "one of two isolated hunts" which might break the law.

Simon Hart from the Countryside Alliance points out that the definitions of legal and illegal hunting are unclear, so police have to make tough decisions. He's concerned about being able to hunt a rat but not a mouse, etc. The Attorney General, Lord Goldsmith, hasn't given any instructions yet on how to deal with hunters who break the law. There might be a meeting soon between the Director of Public Prosecutions and police regarding this.

TheBeaufort Hunt had one pack out on Thursday and promises another hunt next weekend. Hunters can either use artificial scents or "flush out" foxes by shooting them instead of bailing them off. There's no mention of being removed, so they have to stay, which could be a problem if they get stuck.

Tony Banks from the Labour Party is concerned that this issue might disappear soon and think people will ask about it in years. He mentions that without the 1997 ban, hunting with dogs would become part of history like otter hunting or badger baiting. The Conservative Party wants to restore hunting because they have made clear in their previous statements.

Alright, putting all these points together into a concise summary. I'll make sure each main point is covered without adding extra details.
</think>

Fox hunting with dogs is now illegal in England and Wales due to a ban that went into effect overnight. Many hunts are still legal, as hunters can use methods like drag hunting or chase hunting followed by shooting. The Chief Police Spokesman expects most people to obey the law but will challenge "one of two isolated hunts." Simon Hart questions how police ensure no violations occur with unclear definitions of legal and illegal hunting. Lord Goldsmith has not issued instructions on handling hunters, citing a potential meeting with public prosecutors. TheBeaufort Hunt had one pack out and promises another. Hunters can use artificial scents or flush out foxes by shooting them rather than bailing them off. Tony Banks from the Labour Party is concerned this issue will disappear soon and thinks people might ask about it in years, citing a 1997 ban making hunting history like otter hunting. The Conservative Party wants to restore hunting because they've made clear they'll reintroduce it.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ban on fox hunting comes into force in England and Wales, after a new law was implemented overnight. The Attorney General has issued no instructions to police on how they should enforce the ban, which involves hunting with dogs but not shooting foxes. Hunts had been allowed before this law, including those that continue to exist such as Beaufort Hunts. Some animal rights activists argue that the government's decision is a sign of the end for hunting as a legal activity, while others see it as a step towards restoring outdated pursuits. The Attorney General has not yet issued instructions on how to enforce the ban, with police already being asked to make impossible judgments based on vague definitions of legal and ill-legal hunting practices. The Beaufort Hunts have expressed their willingness to continue with the practice of "hunting for an artificial scen". Tony Bank, a Labour MP, sees this as history repeating itself, as other country pursuits such as otter hunting and badger baiting had passed into history due to governmental restrictions.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The ban on foxhunting in England and Wales came into effect overnight, after a legal battle between foxhunt lobbyists and the Attorney General. Hunts are now allowed to hunt with dogs but have to follow strict regulations to ensure they don't break the law. This includes using a one-of-two hunting options or using artificial scents instead of real ones, as per the new law. The Attorney General, Lord Goldsmith, has so far not issued any instructions to police on how they should enforce this ban, but he is expected to consult with stakeholders soon.
phi:2.7b: Hunting with dogs is illegal in England and Wales, but some hunts are expected to continue illegally. The police may face challenges enforcing the ban due to blurred definitions of legal and illegal hunting. The Attorney General has yet to issue instructions on how to deal with hunting violations, and the anti-hunting lobby expects prosecution for clear evidence of illegal hunting practices. Some hunts will be allowed to use artificial scents and flush out foxes as long as they shoot them instead of using hounds.

Some hunts are expected to be out in force this weekend, but the police have acknowledged their duty to investigate allegations of hunting offences. The Attorney General has not yet issued instructions on how to deal with hunters who violate the law. The ban on hunting is controversial, with some expecting it to disappear over time. However, others believe that if the Conservatives gain power, they will restore hunting.

The Countryside Alliance challenges how police will ensure there are no violations of the new ban, pointing out the blurred lines between legal and illegal hunting practices. Attorney General Lord Goldsmith has yet to issue instructions on how police should handle violators, but will consult with relevant authorities soon. Hunters under the new law have options such as mounting hunts for artificial scents or flushing out foxes without setting dogs on them. Some, like Tony Banks, believe the ban will become irrelevant in a few years as former practices like otter hunting and badger baiting fade away, with the Conservative party pledging to restore hunting if elected into government.

Fox hunting with dogs is now illegal in England and Wales, enforced overnight. The Countryside Alliance anticipates many hunts will disregard the ban this weekend, citing ambiguity in the law regarding what constitutes legal hunting. Chief police officer Nigel Yeo expects most hunters to adhere to drag hunting or shooting foxes after being chased. However, Simon Hart of the Countryside Alliance questions how police will enforce the law due to its complex definitions.

The Attorney General, Lord Goldsmith, has not provided specific instructions for enforcing the ban but plans to consult with the Director of Public Prosecutions and the police soon. John Cooper from the League Against Cruel Sports expects authorities to prosecute clear cases of illegal hunting practices.

The Beaufort Hunt is one of several planned to defy the ban this weekend, maintaining they can still flush out foxes without setting their hounds on them. Captain Ian Farquhar, the hunt master, vowed the community would persist until hunting resumes legally.

Labour MP Tony Banks believes the issue will subside in a few years if not for government delays since 1997. He attributes the continuation of fox hunting to Conservative opposition to banning it, suggesting that restoring hunting would be prioritized if they win elections.
reference: We will keep these hounds going, we will keep this community going and in the end we will come back and hunt when hunting is legal again," hunt master, Captain Ian Farquhar, said.Chief police officers spokesman Nigel Yeo said he expected most people would obey the law - by drag hunting or chasing foxes then shooting them.He said police had "acknowledged their duty to investigate allegations of hunting offences".He said police would challenge the "one of two isolated hunts" which are threatening to break the law.He said had the government not prevaricated since 1997 in introducing the ban, hunting with dogs would have passed into history like other former country pursuits such as otter hunting and badger baiting."The definitions of legal and illegal hunting are so blurred that the police are being asked to make impossible judgements.He said he will consult the Director of Public Prosecutions and the police "in the near future" to decide what measures to take with regards to hunting prosecutions."You can hunt a rat, but not a mouse, a rabbit but not a hare, an artificial scent, but not a real one," he said.
